subject: Science
title: Metallic Bonds: A Sea of Electrons
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Metallic Bonds: A Sea of Electrons.

hook.text: Metals conduct electricity because their electrons roam freely like a shared pool.

buildup.text: In metals, outer electrons aren't attached to any one atom. They drift through the structure.

discovery.text: This 'electron sea' carries charge through the metal â€” that's electrical conductivity.

twist.text: The same electron sea lets metals bend without breaking. Atoms slide over each other easily.

climax.text: Gold can be hammered into sheets just a few atoms thick â€” because of metallic bonding.

punchline.text: Metals share electrons with everybody. That generosity is what makes them useful.

quiz.question: Why can metals conduct electricity?
options: Their outer electrons move freely through the structure
They contain charged protons on the surface
Heat from the environment creates current
